Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Radical Precursor Chemistry in the Northeast United States
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (PRF) supports the participation of an early career female scientist in a large NSF-supported field campaign to measure nitrogen compounds in the atmosphere. The Wintertime Investigation of Transport, Emissions, and Reactivity (WINTER) campaign scheduled during January-February 2015, in the Mid-Atlantic region of the Northeastern U.S. focuses on atmospheric multiphase chemical transformations that generally occur more slowly in wintertime, enabling the resulting pollutants to be transported over wider geographic areas downwind of source regions. The results of this research are important for understanding how nitrogen chemistry influences air quality and climate.

Measurements of nitryl chloride (ClNO2) will be made with a chemical ionization mass spectrometer utilizing iodide ion-molecule clusters (I- CIMS). Measurements of NO, NO2, N2O5, NO3 and O3 will be made using a cavity ring-down spectrometer (CRDS). These instruments will be deployed on the NSF/NCAR C-130 aircraft along with many additional instruments being contributed by other investigators. Other related compounds being measured include Cl2, HONO, HNO3, HNCO, HCl and peroxy nitrates.

The three primary research objectives of WINTER are to: 1) Characterize the chemical transformations of wintertime emissions via multiphase, nocturnal, and photochemical processes; 2) Assess the dominant mechanisms of secondary aerosol formation and quantify the geographical distribution of inorganic and organic aerosol types during winter; and 3) Constrain wintertime emission inventories of key pollutants for urban areas, power plants, and agricultural areas, and characterize their export over the North Atlantic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Reactive nitrogen (NOx, composed of NO and NO2) and the chemistry it undergoes play a vital role in atmospheric chemistry. NOx is emitted from a variety of sources, both natural and human-influenced. NOx chemistry impacts levels of ozone (O3) in the atmosphere, as well as particulate formation, both of which have significant impacts on human and ecosystem health. While NOx chemistry has been heavily studied in the summer, wintertime chemistry is less well understood. The major differences between summer and winter in the northeastern United States that influence the chemistry are length of day, temperature and differing emissions patterns.

Under this grant, Dr. Fibiger participated in measurement of reactive nitrogen during the Wintertime INvestigation of Transport, Emissions and Reactivity (WINTER) on the NSF/NCAR C-130 aircraft. The WINTER campaign was conducted in February and March 2015, based out of NASA Langley in Hampton, Virginia. The campaign consisted of 13 research flights looking at atmospheric chemistry in urban areas, power plant plumes, and off-shore plumes and how the chemistry differs from summertime. Dr. Fibiger was primarily responsible for deploying a cavity ring-down instrument to measure various oxidized nitrogen species and used that data to evaluate wintertime chemistry.

In particular, Dr. Fibiger has investigated the nighttime evolution of power plant plumes in the winter. Overnight, NOx will undergo chemistry that can either remove it from the atmosphere (through formation of nitric acid) or it can form reservoir species that will break down to reform as NOx the next day. If the NOx is removed, it will not participate in O3 chemistry or particulate formation the next day. Past studies have shown the primary control on the rate of NOx removal is how quickly the power plant plume mixes with background air. In contrast, this study has found that there are other reaction rates that can stop NOx removal, regardless of plume mixing. The local atmospheric composition is vital to determining how much NOx is removed overnight.

In addition, this study has provided data which will help evaluate the controls on formation of nitric acid (which removes NOx from the atmosphere) and other species (which reform NOx the next day) overnight in urban plumes. Several research flights followed urban plumes from New York City over the coast, as they aged. By evaluating these data, we can increase our understanding of how urban NOx reacts overnight and how far it can travel to influence atmospheric chemistry.
